image.title: The latest news from News Center.

item.title: Online registration for Neutrino 2016 is now open
item.creator: leah
item.description: Online registration for Neutrino 2016 is now open and available via the conference website http://neutrino2016.iopconfs.org. The key dates for to note are: Abstract submission deadline (poster): March 14, 2016 Financial support application deadline: March 31, 2016 Early registration deadline: May 2, 2016 Online accommodation booking deadline: May 2, 2016 Registration deadline: June 17, 2016 The first announcement may be found at: http://neutrino2016.iopconfs.org/IOP/media/uploaded/EVIOP/event_582/NEUTRINO_2016_-_1st_ANNOUNCEMENT__A4_.pdf Further details may be found at the conference website.
item.comment:
Online registration for Neutrino 2016 is now open and available via the conference website http://neutrino2016.iopconfs.org .

The key dates for to note are:
Abstract submission deadline (poster): March 14, 2016
Financial support application deadline: March 31, 2016
Early registration deadline: May 2, 2016
Online accommodation booking deadline: May 2, 2016
Registration deadline: June 17, 2016
The first announcement may be found at:
http://neutrino2016.iopconfs.org/IOP/media/uploaded/EVIOP/event_582/NEUTRINO_2016_-_1st_ANNOUNCEMENT__A4_.pdf

Further details may be found at the conference website .

item.title: Physicists may have discovered a new “tetraquark” particle
item.creator: leah
item.description: From Scientific American , Feb. 26, 2016: Evidence for a never-before-seen particle containing four types of quark has shown up in data from the Tevatron collider at Fermilab.
item.comment: From Scientific American , Feb. 26, 2016: Evidence for a never-before-seen particle containing four types of quark has shown up in data from the Tevatron collider at Fermilab.

item.title: New parental leave policy and tax-free commuter benefit program
item.creator: debseb
item.description: Fermilab recognizes that supporting employees in their efforts to balance career and family life remains a crucial benefit. To help support that balance, Iâ€™m pleased to announce the launch of a new Fermilab parental leave policy effective today, March 1, and a tax-free commuter benefit program that will begin on June 1.
item.comment:
Fermilab recognizes that supporting employees in their efforts to balance career and family life remains a crucial benefit. To help support that balance, a new Fermilab parental leave policy is available beginning today, March 1, and a tax-free commuter benefit program that will begin on June 1.

Parental leave policy

Following a birth or adoption, the new policy provides six weeks of paid time off for the eligible primary caregiver and one week of paid time off for the eligible secondary caregiver. The parental leave policy offers flexibility with a variety of time off and return to work schedules, based on what works for you and your supervisor.

To ensure you receive the full benefits that you are allowed, remember to notify your HR partner at least 30 days prior to births or adoptions. Please contact the Benefits department if you have any questions or would like additional information on the new policy.

Tax-free commuter benefit program

A tax-free commuter benefit program is available for employees who commute to work by bus, train or vanpool. To begin receiving benefits in June, you will need to contact the Benefits department by March 21 to start the enrollment process. Once the Benefits department has enrolled you in the program via Payflex, you can pay both your transit fares and fees to park at the train or bus station with pre-tax dollars to help save on commuting costs. Employees may join the program monthly by contacting the Benefits department .

item.title: Special Seminar: Careers in Data Science and Data Engineering – March 9
item.creator: boj
item.description: Careers in Data Science and Data Engineering Kathy Copic, Director of Growth at Insight Data Science Wednesday, March 9, at 1 p.m. in One West. Data science teams in industry analyze some of the most interesting data ever collected, in fields like health care, education, media, entertainment, transportation, and more. Scientists and engineers from high-energy physics and other quantitative fields are playing key roles in transforming the way companies work with data to impact our daily lives. Copic will discuss... More »
item.comment:
Careers in Data Science and Data Engineering Kathy Copic, Director of Growth at Insight Data Science Wednesday, March 9, at 1 p.m. in One West.

Data science teams in industry analyze some of the most interesting data ever collected, in fields like health care, education, media, entertainment, transportation, and more. Scientists and engineers from high-energy physics and other quantitative fields are playing key roles in transforming the way companies work with data to impact our daily lives.

Copic will discuss the data science landscape based on her experience working with over 500 Insight alumni, who are now data scientists and data engineers at over 100 companies and nonprofits, including Facebook, Apple, Google, Twitter, Reddit, Netflix, The New York Times, NBC, Khan Academy, Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, and the Broad Institute.

The Insight Fellows Program is a training fellowship for graduate students and postdocs designed to bridge the gap between academia and a career in data science and engineering. Insight provides seven-week, full-time, postdoctoral training fellowships in Silicon Valley, New York City, and Boston. It offers full-tuition scholarships, dedicated office space, and self-directed, project-based learning under the guidance of top industry mentors.

Kathy Copic is the director of growth at Insight Data Science. Before Insight, she worked in experimental particle physics at labs including CERN, Fermilab, SLAC and CESR. She earned her Ph.D. in physics at the University of Michigan working on CDF, was a postdoc at Columbia on ATLAS, and was a staff scientist at Lawrence Berkeley National Lab working with ATLAS and the Particle Data Group. http://insightdatascience.com

item.title: Tcl Programming
item.creator: bbrooks
item.description: The Professional Development Office has scheduled a 2-day course in Tcl Programming. This course is designed to give you basic knowledge of the Tcl language and the ability to write Tcl programs. For more information and enrollment go to: http://www-esh.fnal.gov/pls/default/schedule.show_course_details?cid=9541

item.title: Nintendo Wii Console Plus
item.creator: rwalton
item.description: Complete Nintendo Wii console with all cables and accessories, including upgraded sensor bar, 2 nunchuks, 4 remotes, many games; includes Wii-Fit with all cables, etc. All documentation, manuals, etc. included. Only sold together. $150 obo. Call 630-247-7320 or email rodwalt9@gmail.com for pictures, info, etc.

item.title: Fermilab video conferencing monthly maintenance
item.creator: marcia
item.description: The Core Computing Division is initiating a standard monthly maintenance window to update the Fermilab video conference equipment infrastructure. Fermilab video conference calls (IP, not phone) may drop during the maintenance window, at which point you should attempt to reconnect to the video conference system. The maintenance window will take place on the first Tuesday of every month from approximately 8:30 to 9:15 a.m. Central starting on Tuesday, March 1. Please submit a Service Desk request if you cannot reconnect... More »
item.comment:
The Core Computing Division is initiating a standard monthly maintenance window to update the Fermilab video conference equipment infrastructure. Fermilab video conference calls (IP, not phone) may drop during the maintenance window, at which point you should attempt to reconnect to the video conference system.

The maintenance window will take place on the first Tuesday of every month from approximately 8:30 to 9:15 a.m. Central starting on Tuesday, March 1. Please submit a Service Desk request if you cannot reconnect to a video conference call or if you experience conference call issues outside of the maintenance window.

item.title: Improve your science communication skills March 1 or March 2 at 8:30 in Ramsey Auditorium
item.creator: katie
item.description: The experts from the Alan Alda Center for Communicating Science at Stony Brook University will present two one-hour plenary, interactive sessions on improving your science communication skills. Anyone looking to improve their skills is invited to attend either session on Tuesday, March 1, or Wednesday, March 2, from 8:30 to 9:30 in Ramsey Auditorium. During the sessions, Alan Alda Center staff will discuss the challenges of communicating to different audiences, use interactive examples to touch on jargon in science communication... More »
item.comment:
The experts from the Alan Alda Center for Communicating Science at Stony Brook University will present two one-hour plenary, interactive sessions on improving your science communication skills.

Anyone looking to improve their skills is invited to attend either session on Tuesday, March 1, or Wednesday, March 2, from 8:30 to 9:30 in Ramsey Auditorium.

During the sessions, Alan Alda Center staff will discuss the challenges of communicating to different audiences, use interactive examples to touch on jargon in science communication and engage you in the concept of distilling your messages for the public.

If you have any questions or are interested in signing up for future communication training opportunities, please contact Katie Yurkewicz ( katie@fnal.gov , x3351).
